thread.title: If the election was based on Twitter popularity who would win the battle for number 10?

author: Rob Grant
title: If the election was based on Twitter popularity who would win the battle for number 10?
text:
If the election was based on Twitter popularity who would win the battle for number 10? We've looked at the popularity of the major parties on social media site Twitter Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
Labour would easily come top of an election based on political party Twitter accounts - but they would still fall short of a majority. 
We analysed the official Twitter accounts of the main parties in Britain in the final leg of the election campaign from June 1 to June 7. 
Labour shared by far the most popular tweets - every 140-character comment from them garnered an average of 593 retweets and 581 likes. 
This compared to just 173 for each tweet from the Conservatives. 
The Greens outdid the Lib Dems, scoring 141 average retweets compared to 118 for Tim Farron’s party. 
Each tweet from UKIP was retweeted an average of 68 times, the SNP 122 and Plaid Cymru 19. 
Compressing all these numbers into a 632-seat House of Commons would give Labour 304 seats in a proportional system. People wait in the rain as Labour Leader Jeremy Corbyn delivers a speech at a rally next to the Sage building on June 5, 2017 in Gateshead (Photo: Getty Images Europe) 
This would be an improvement on the 229 they have going into the election, but unfortunately for whoever runs Labour’s social media account it wasn’t quite enough for a majority. Read More General Election 2017 LIVE: Polling stations open as Newcastle and the North East start casting their votes 
They might have to make an alliance with the Green Party , who would have an impressive 72 seats - some 71 better than they currently have. 
The Conservatives would be well down on 89 seats, compared to the 330 represented by Theresa May’s party. 
Labour’s most popular tweet was an endorsement of the NHS and Labour by American comedian Rob Delaney, which was retweeted 7,764 times. 
Of course, Twitter is not a representative sample of the British public - politicians on the Right since at least Richard Nixon in the 1960s have talked about a ‘silent majority’ of voters who support them. 
The Tories have been focusing on Brexit in their social media campaigning. 
The @Conservatives account mentioned Brexit 73 times during the final week of campaigning, more than any other issue. 
The Tories have also been hammering Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn - his name cropped up almost as frequently as Theresa May. 
The @Conservatives account mentioned ‘Corbyn’ 59 times, compared to 63 for ‘Theresa’ and ‘May’. 
Labour meanwhile have been focusing on the NHS, mentioning the health service 29 times. 
The Lib Dems have been talking about Brexit more than anything else but obviously from the other perspective to the Conservatives, mentioning leaving the EU 40 times. How the House of Commons would look: How the House of Commons would look if the election was based on Twitter Data unit Read More
